comments.commentBody: Inequality is a fact of life, but so is discontentment with inequality. The decades immediately following WWII saw the highest and fastest-increasing standard of living in the US, and they were characterized by very high taxes on high incomes (albeit with large deductions for investments in certain economic sectors) and by greater income equality than we now have. The wealthy were mostly agreeable to these policies because US economic growth was in their best interest also; however, with the rise of the world economy, this in no longer the case. The belief that policies designed to promote greater income equality are destructive to the entrepreneurial spirit and to economic growth is a myth promoted by the ultra-wealthy to further their own goals, not the goal of US economic growth.

I have over 30 years of military service working with soldiers with traumatic problems related to combat operations. I have been trained in most models of psychotherapy. I too was skeptical of EMDR for many years - but nothing else I was using (the other models) was very effective. The first soldier I treated with EMDR was accompanied by his spouse when he showed up for his third appointment. She stated, "I just wanted to stop by and thank you. I don't know what you are doing with my husband, but I want to tell you whatever it is works - I have him back the way he was before he went to Iraq!"

I am in the trenches everyday day working with active duty soldiers and veterans. Our military and veterans deserve efficacious treatment in a timely manner. The VA/DOD Clinical Guidelines (2010) recognize EMDR as being efficacious in the treatment of adult trauma. Those Guidelines recognize EMDR as being among three other models of psychotherapy that are efficacious in treatment. I use EMDR every day and witness the results. Discussion is always nice; I enjoy it - witnessing the true results that EMDR can accomplish in a few sessions is convincing! That is why the military sends personnel to my center (Soldier Center) specifically for EMDR treatment on a regular basis from across the nation - it works.

E. C. Hurley, Ph.D
COL, USA (Ret)
Director, Soldier Center
www.Soldier-Center.com

The solution to this problem is pretty simple.

90 days to respond? Many of these places have been around for years.
Lawyers profiting? If they can't make money off these cases, there will be no compliance.

The disabled plaintiffs are not real customers? Perhaps not, but it may be the case that many potential disabled customers on seeing the inaccessibility problems, decided to turn away rather than try to fight with the owners to educate them on the law. A really, do you think you'd be welcome in an establishment that you just sued?

A single person is not a political party.  Even if that one person wins, there will be nobody in the other branches to cooperate, and no second act. the best response I've seen by anyone yet! Honestly veganism isn't for everyone. It's time-consuming, restrictive, expensive, and denies people things they love. Why not just try to be...gasp...HEALTHIER! This would involve eating fewer meats, and have the corresponding environmental benefits.

I'm tired all of these articles advocating what amounts to nutritional extremism. Great for you guys if it works for you...more power to you. Seriously though, most people don't have the time, money, knowledge or desire to do this (notice that just about all vegans are upper-class white people), so it would be MUCH more effective to promote a more sensible path aimed at reducing meat consumption.
Nonsense. There's a wide variety of designs that are accessible.

"I think my body asks me what it needs..."

Unfortunately, too many people's bodies are asking for fats and sugars, and super-size that, please.

American restaurants and processed food manufacturers have been poisoning us, for years. Buyer beware.

By following a diet similar to what has been outlined in this article, both my wife (age 60) and I (70) have lost 20# in three months, with more to come, we're quite confident. It's not about "going vegan" as an answer to an ethics dilemma as it is an answer to "how can I be healthy?"

I'm glad you are healthy and hope you stay that way for a long time. The issue isn't whether we should feel guilty about eating meat. It's pretty well established that a diet that is heavy on meat is not as healthy as a plant based diet. That's ultimately a personal choice. The greater issue is whether there are enough resources for everyone on the planet to eat meat.  The land and water usage required to produce meat is many times greater than what is required to grow plants. (which can sustain many more people) Additionally, the pollution caused by this meat production is wrecking the environment. It's worth reading Michael Pollen's works along with Mark Bittman's. Not asking you to join the 'cult' of vegetarianism or veganism but it's worth digging deeper into the thinking behind these movements.

I consume vegetables, but I'm also enjoy meat as well as animal derived food.  I feel not remorse neither guilty enjoying food.  Never being sick not being fat I think my body asks me what it needs.  As per my wallet…I buy what I can afford and give thanks to the vegetables and animal kingdom for keeping me well.  My more effusive respects.
Sleazy lawyers! If the disabled find these situations is one thing but to scout them out and then recruit the offended is lower than low.

As part of our convert family's religious practice as an Eastern Orthodox Christians, we are vegans approximately 180 days of the year. A vegan diet is part of our pre-Christmas and pre-Pascha (Easter) discipline, and we eat vegan meals almost every Wednesday and Friday as well to commemorate Christ's Passion and death. Although we eat meat and dairy during non-fast periods, our red meat consumption has declined dramatically--to the point that we are much more vegetarian than omnivore--and healthier and happier for it.

I like to think that, as semi-vegans, our family is eating more responsibly, reducing both our environmental footprint by eating lower on the food chain and leaving a place at the table for others to eat as well.

As someone who was a vegan for 6 years, the word is DON'T DO IT! It's extremely unhealthy in the long term. As a woman, it's even worse to go vegan, unless you're post-menopausal. Eventually, after five years, my body used up all it's stores of various minerals and vitamins. I looked great but was tired and felt weak all the time. My strength was giving out and then my adrenals gave out and, eventually, doctor after doctor after doctor (including acupuncturists and naturopaths) told me to start eating at least eggs.
Veganism is a crock and very difficult (i.e., expensive) to do properly. Unless you're a nutritionist, and a good one, you should not be avoiding animal proteins. It's just another fashion and I'm sorry I fell for it.
Thats awesome! Good luck!

Your clients might do just as well, if not better, giving up sugar and grains but leaving meat and dairy in moderation. Veganism as practiced by many people means a diet dominated by starches, sugars and agribusiness-grown cereal grains. That will inevitably lead to obesity and diabetes.

I appreciate the light the Times is shining on American cuisine choices. Going vegan is not as difficult as many people think. I am a nutritionist and I work with people in chronic pain and the aging. Everyday I support people in giving up meat, dairy, gluten and sugar and the difference that this makes is beyond inspiring! Chronic pain significantly decreases within days. We have created a very supportive web site that will be live in a few days called ameatfreemonth.org We encourage people to live meat free for 30 days. We'll have numerous resources, and very inspiring footage of people that have already given up consuming meat for 30 days. Research has shown that it only takes 21 days to create new habits and patterning. You may want to try it for yourself! You'll be delighted at how much more energy, clarity and well being that you feel. Most Americans hugely underestimate the power of the food they consume and are significantly mis-educated about how to eat. The sustainability of our planet depends upon the food choices of every individual...it's wise to think beyond just ourselves.
